profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Speight-McKenney Family papers contains correspondence, calling cards, photographs, poems, songs, and an herbarium. The collection was primarily created by Florence Speight, daughter of prominent early Waco citizen Joseph Speight.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Florence Josephine Speight McKenney (1847-1922), the first daughter of prominent early Waco citizens Joseph and Josephine S. Pruitt Speight, was born in Mississippi on 1847 September 21. It is unknown what education she received, but she married E.A. McKenney after the Civil War, in 1868. E.A. McKenney was originally from Canada, served as a Captain in the 6th Texas Cavalry during the Civil War, and later became Mayor of Waco after the war. The couple had six children together. Florence McKenny passed away on 1922 December 26, and is buried in Oakwood Cemetery in Waco, Texas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Speight-McKenney Family collection contains a variety of materials, including letters, financial and legal documents, photographs, calling cards, poems and songs, and an herbarium. The financial and legal documents include several Civil War-era documents, including a certificate pledging $20,000 for the Confederate war effort, signed by leading Waco citizens of the time such as S.P. Ross, George Barnard, and E.A. McKenney. Many of the calling cards have been personalized with miniature sketches, though it is not known if this was done by Florence Speight. The herbarium preserves around 100 plant and flower specimens in a scrapbook created by Florence Speight when she was fourteen years old.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Speight-McKenney Family collection was housed in numbered and titled folders prior to recent processing. Existing folder titles were mostly retained. Various inventories and an early finding aid were done for this collection.
Currently, the collection contains one series: I. Collected Materials.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Speight-McKenney Family collection, Accession #10, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Paul T. Fisher. Released on 2021-08-06.

relatedmaterial.bibref: Ryan, Terri Jo. "Preserved Flowers from 1800s Offer Glimpse into Waco's Past." Waco Tribune Herald. 2010 February 13.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains various materials created by Florence Speight McKenney and E.A. McKenney, including financial and legal documents, correspondence, songs and poems, art, photographs, and a herbarium. This series is in poor condition.
